ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great understanding of the basics of American politics; from the nation's founding to the present day, Trump, and the media.

Being raised in England I did not know a lot about the structure and theory of American Government. I definitely learned a lot in that regard which I think will be beneficial going forward in other US political science classes.
This course nuanced the systems of American government, and it encouraged students to question their functions.
A basic understanding of the fundamental institutions and factors in American Politics.
this course allowed me more insight in the American Political System and the way in which each branch of government not only interacts with one other but with the public as well.
Very very broad introductory overview of American politics.
Knowledge about the history and workings of American politics
I gained a basic understanding of the structure of the American government and reinforced my knowledge of early American history.

Literally nothing. Not to be dismissive but this course did not teach me anything that I had not already learned in a US History class or the news. I hated taking this course and found it to be incredibly boring which is a shame because I think the topic has the potential to be taught in an engaging and exciting way.
Great introductory background of American politics.
A general introduction to American politics and its evolution throughout history
I developed an intricate knowledge of the American political system. The writing assignments were useful in developing argumentative writing skills.
basics in American politics
Reinforced, through repetition, my understanding of American politics and government.

I reviewed a lot about the American federal government: branches, separations of powers, Constitution, and the Bill of Rights. I got lots of good, general information on concepts like the media, interest groups, and direct democracy. There was a couple really interesting lectures on theories about the government. Most of the information wasn't super new to me, and was similar to high school government/US history course information.
I learned about the American political system and developed better writing skills
I learned a lot about the american government system both in the past and present
I became a very efficient and effective writer. I learned great knowledge on the American political system that is necessary for my major and to any job as an educated adult.
Survey course on American government and politics; Learned how to build and developed arguments related to issues within American government and politics
I learned about how Congress, the executive branch, and Supreme Court function with reference to the founding fathers and constitution.
I did not learn anything useful in this course.  The only insight I developed was that the standards the Poli Sci department uses to screen its professors is seriously lacking.
structure of the american government

I strengthened skills in writing and note-taking. I was able to reflect knowledge through all of the assigned papers and essays throughout the course. Additionally, I strengthened organizational skills with my notes.
This course gave a basic overview of American politics & political systems, though it sometimes felt broad and oversimplified.
My knowledge in american politics and the process that is the American Government.
Critical thinking
I gained a solid background about the American political system and how it has evolved over time.
I developed a strong foundation for the political system of American society.
Critical thinking, annotating, supporting arguments
A basic understanding of American politics
I learned intricacies about the foundations of American politics and democracy.

This class was a survey of American Politics. We learned about the history of the U.S. government, the three branches of government in-depth, the 'Electoral Connection,' civil liberties, civil rights, and direct democracy. I also improved my writing skills through the class assignments.

I learned to write clear thesis statements and organize essays in a way that follows the thesis and utilizes key concepts correctly. I also learned a lot about the three branches of government, the impact of media, public opinion, campaign financing, and I can go on and on.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses, amazing class! Fairdosi is a great lecturer and the team of TAs was incredible. Lectures are easy to follow and interesting. I can't say enough great things.

This course covers a lot of important material, and the professor is very engaging. It would benefit from a longer block of it; we were often cut short as class ended, and we were limited in the information we could cover. I also found the writing assignment to be jarring after having very little written work for the rest of the semester.

I think the strengths of this course was that it did not assume anyone's level of knowledge of American politics and was truly and Introduction.  I think this course can be improved by having the notes of the lecture posted in case certain points were missed or if the lecture runs over time.

Weaknesses: lectures are quite slow. Wish we could have gone a bit deeper into the topics. Felt like it was taught below the level of a Yale intro political science class.

Strengths: Low-stress. And TA Jack Greenberg really gave it his all!
Section was great. Lecture content was very straightforward but could have been more engaging at times. I liked the format of the assessments (midterm, paper, final).

This is a very basic course that delivers exactly what its title says: an introduction to American politics. With that said, a lot of it was reviewing American history rather than discussing the connections of different parts of government today.

I have no strengths of this course to offer except for the actual workload it's very manageable. 
I found the lecture style to be terrible. Prof Fairdosi just puts up a list of text on to the screen and then reads from his notes in the same spot for an hour twice a week. Incredibly disengaging and hard to pay attention. He also kept plugging his Congress course from next semester.
Class was at times a bit disorganized, concepts were never fully explored in depth.

Strengths: generally engaging content that covered a lot of important ground, in a topic as broad as American politics
Weaknesses: lectures generally ran over time and were rather disorganized at times, leading to some content being covered disproportionately compared to others

Strengths: the lecture plan was well organized to facilitate learning, and Prof. Fairdosi is an authority on the topic. Section is actually interesting, which is a welcome break. 
Weaknesses: the course demanded nearly no engagement apart from occasional writing assignments. 
Improvement: more readings would be nice, especially since the textbook is mind-numbingly boring.
I wish the teacher made lecture slides to take notes off of
As an intro class it was very good but could be improved by diving a little more into certain parts of government.

A strength is that you get a good general survey of the history and current landscape of American politics. The course is also not a ton of work, and is very manageable. A weakness is that I didn't learn quite as much new information as I would've hoped. I wasn't super engaged in lectures or section. There wasn't a lot fo feedback on work.

I thought the lectures were easy to follow and interesting. One weakness was we didnt always follow the syllabus towards the end because of lack of time. My TA gave great feedback on the writing assignments
i thought the lectures were interesting and the sections were well structured to cover all the material
Strengths: well-organized course, professor makes content very accessible
This course could have been a bit faster so that we could cover more material. However, the material that was covered was interesting and useful to a thorough understanding of American government.

This class made me feel like I was back in high school and not in a good way.  Our textbook was probably written for a 9th grade audience, and Prof. Fairdosi taught the class similarly.  Prof. Faridosi essentially read off of his lecture notes verbatim for the entirety of every lecture in an incredibly monotonous tone of voice.  I get that this was an intro course, but Prof. Fairdosi treated us like we had never heard of something called politics before.  One gem was "Political scientists want to know what people think, but it turns out we can't actually ask everyone what they think, so we do something called a poll based on something called a sample."  Similarly, we spent about 5 minutes of one class defining what gerrymandering is, and several more minutes of another defining a legal brief.  There's a way to teach an engaging and informative intro course that doesn't assume a deep background in the material, but this was not even close to being it.

Professor Fairdosi also seemed to lack a basic understanding of the courses material.  For example, he informed the class that there are four freedoms protected under the First Amendment, when there are famously five.  Moreover, we fell super far behind the syllabus, meaning that there was a decent chunk of information that we simply did not cover.  At best, it felt like Prof. Fairdosi just treated this class as a way to advertise his class on the U.S. Congress, given that he mentioned it at least once a week while lecturing.  

This class could be improved by completely rewriting the syllabus and not letting Prof. Fairdosi within a mile radius of the classroom.
more videos and other engaging things in lecture

I feel there were many strengths with this course. Firstly, I enjoyed the structure and outline of the class. I feel the layout and use of papers to reflect knowledge was very engaging. All of the assigned papers/essays allowed creativity and knowledge to combine. Secondly, I loved the teaching style and use of a lecture outline. Each lecture was very organized and easy to follow. The lectures inspired creativity. Lastly, I loved the flexibility and understanding that the professor and Teaching Fellow had for classmates throughout the semester. Personally, a weakness of the course was the class location. Overall, the strengths of the course outweighed the one weakness regarding the location.

Strength: good general overview of American politics for those who aren't too familiar with how it works. Weakness: The lectures sometimes felt dry and it was hard to be engaged in the subject material not that the subject material isn't interesting, but the way in which it was taught.
strengths: great flexibility in assignments and lectures. no weaknesses
Excellent
Lectures were interesting yet at a slow pace, and very repetitive of the textbook. Readings outside of the textbook would diversify the information.
Both the Professor and the TF were amazing at presenting the course concepts in clear ways and the suggested reading enhanced the concepts we learned about.
could be cool to bringer a speaker in if possible, Prof. Fairdosi is a great lecturer though.
Was hard to stay engaged as lecture was not interactive at all
I think the strengths were a very robust lecture system with thorough outlines, the only weakness was that we would not get to everything in an outlined lecture all the time.

Strengths: great lectures, clear rubrics for assignments, interesting readings and assignments, 
Weaknesses: the discussion sections lacked structure and did not add to my learning experience

Professor Fairdosi is extremely engaging and very passionate about the topics at hand. Since it is a lecture, there isn't room to ask questions during class time. The experience also heavily relies on which TA you get, which can be good or bad depending on which one you get.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES, take this class. Fairdosi is amazing and the class is a great intro to politics for any major.
I would recommend it to someone who wants an overview of the structure of US government.
This is an interesting course that could be useful to anyone interacting with the United States, so I do recommend it.
Yes! Great class, easy lectures and a good introduction.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student if they were interested. it has been my favorite class this semester. It truly provides and insight to the American political system but also allows you to form your own opinions in the way you think about politics.

It's a gut. If you want a gut it's a good class. If you want to see if the PoliSci major is a good fit for you, I would recommend taking a seminar and only taking this foundational course if you are required to.
Yes, especially if you aren't a politics major or are international and just want to learn more about US politics. It was interesting and didn't contribute a lot to my workload this semester.

Only if you have not taken a course on American government before. After declaring as a Political Science major, I decided to take this course as I had never taken a class on American government before. However, if you have already taken a class like AP US Government in high school, I don't think it is necessary to take this course, especially since its main textbook is one used in AP US Gov classrooms.
No, definitely not unless you have to. I found this course to be incredibly boring. I dreaded going to lecture.
If its a distributional requirement, the sure. Otherwise, there are better political science courses out there to take.
Yes - a good introduction to American politics, if you're really looking for a truly rudimentary, simple introduction.
I would recommend this class over other PLSC intro courses, which tend to be less interesting. Don't expect to work too hard, or to learn an incredible amount.

yes if you are interested in American history/politics
not a lot of work
If you don't know much about American politics then yes but if you already do I would consider taking a more difficult class.

I'd recommend it to a student who didn't learn a ton of in depth stuff on American politics in high school or to someone with a general interest that is looking for a course with a manageable workload. I wouldn't recommend it to someone looking to dive into the subject in depth or really improve their writing.

I would if theyre from another country or not very familiar with the American political system. I wouldnt if they are pretty well versed in American politics because its a pretty introductory course and can get boring if you know the material
Yes absolutely, i really enjoyed the lectures and the professor

I would recommend this course to any major. It is a prefect course for those intending to major in Political science, and a comfortable course for those who are looking to fulfill their social science credit. The material was especially manageable to follow and was achievable through regular attendance.

If you need this for a pre-req or you need to learn about American gov't and politics to better understand content in other future courses(i.e., you didn't take/learn a lot from AP U.S. Gov in high school), then definitely! Otherwise, you might find the course a bit dry.
You should take the class if you want a good introduction to civics and the American political system.

Absolutely not.  If you have to take this class for a requirement, find another way to fulfill the requirement.  If you want to learn about American Politics (or really just learn period) this class will not help with that goal at all.  Run.
YES! A must for Political Science majors or students wanting to learn about government.
yes it is a very good introduction to the american political system
I would and I have recommended this course to other students. The course inspires interest in Political Science and pushes for student engagement.

I would not recommend this course to people who are excited about politics and already have a general understanding about the American Political system, unless you really need/want to take it as an introductory political science course.
yes, if you want an introduction to american politics i highly recommend
Of course, excellent professor & TA
Yes, if you haven't taken AP Gov or an equivalent. It's an easy course, but pretty surface level.

I would recommend this course, both because the content gave a solid foundation for understanding many of the current issues society is still facing today, as well as the excellent presentation of the concepts throughout the course.
Yes was a good course for an intro to poli sci and see if that was something I wanted to do
I would recommend this course unless you know a lot about government already because if that is the case, you will not be intellectually challenged by the course.
I would recommend this course to a student without any background knowledge in American government and politics. This class is a great survey of American politics.

YES; take this course please!!!!!!! The topics that were discussed were extremely engaging, and Professor Fairdosi is an amazing teacher who is passionate about everything he does. Not only did I feel comfortable in that class, but I felt encouraged to think critically and argue both sides regarding political topics. The lectures, for me at least, always went by fast which is really nice. Additionally, this semester the midterm and final were open-note, and we had several days to complete them. The TAs are very helpful in answering questions. The one thing I will say is that some of the readings are quite extensive, and the font on the book is small.
